Graphical abstract Herein, ultra-stable Y zeolite (USY) catalysts modified with iron doping (1, 3, and 5 wt%) using FeCl3•6H2O as a precursor have been investigated. Detailed characterization of the synthesized catalysts was implemented through different analytical techniques including XRD, FTIR, UV–vis DRS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, N2 physisorption, EDX, FESEM, ICP-EOS, and XRF. The strong Lewis acidity of the precursor bestowed improved acidic properties to the parent USY besides a satisfactory partial dealumination of the zeolite structure. The optimal dispersion and structural properties were obtained in the case of 1 wt% doping of iron, which eventually led to superb olefin productivity (more than 56 wt%) in the upgrading of refinery fuel oil at mild operating conditions (atmospheric pressure and 550 °C). The optimum catalyst (1Fe/USY) has undergone further experiments with varying temperatures and space velocities to assess the apparent kinetics based on the Arrhenius model. A threefold increase in the space velocity (from 18.3 to 54.9 h–1) only slightly reduced the olefin productivity of the catalyst (to 47.1 wt%), which was still notable from a heavy feedstock. Reduction of the reaction temperature to 450 °C led to a decrease in the olefins yield to less than a half (23.3 wt%). Overall, the modified catalysts were capable of producing a high amount of light olefins from heavy fuel oil, with an orientation toward propylene as the most favored building block in the petrochemical industries. Keywords Catalytic cracking Iron Fuel oil Light olefins USY Zeolite 1 Introduction Light olefins (C2H4, C3H6, and C4H8) are the largest volume building blocks for many chemicals and petrochemicals [1–3]. These starting materials are produced industrially via steam cracking [4–9], catalytic cracking [10–13], metathesis [14], dehydrogenation [15–17], and dimerization [18–20]. Over the years, intensive research has been conducted on converting heavy and extra-heavy hydrocarbons to products of growing worldwide demands, such as light olefins and liquid fuels [5,9,11,21,22]. Thermal and catalytic cracking of these hydrocarbon sources have been accepted as reliable approaches for obtaining light olefins, namely ethylene, propylene, and butenes and liquid fuels viz. gasoline and diesel fuel. Although thermal cracking of heavy hydrocarbon feedstocks is still considered as the main commercial solution, it suffers from high energy consumption, carbon emission, coke formation, and low selectivity towards targeted products [9,23]. In contrast, catalytic cracking of hydrocarbon feedstocks benefits from its product-oriented nature and its mild operating conditions and hence attracts a great deal of attention. Hitherto, a quite large number of catalysts with either acidic or metallic active sites have been proposed for this type of reaction [13]. The refinery fuel oil is one of the most economically feasible but technically most complicated feedstocks that may be used in a catalytic cracking process. To opt for an appropriate catalyst for upgrading of such a heavy feedstock, the selectivity toward targeted products together with its lifetime are the two substantial features which should be taken into account. Zeolites and other aluminosilicate formulations are the most frequently applied catalysts in this field [24–26]. Among these, the ultra-stable Y zeolite (USY) with its unique properties such as strong Brønsted acidic sites, significant hydrothermal stability at severe operating conditions, and efficient pore sizes for the cracking reactions is still receiving much research interest as the heart of the fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) process [10,27–30]. Although zeolites are the most suitable catalysts for cracking of heavy hydrocarbons, various types of surface modifications and structural improvements have been reported to enhance their cracking performance, optimize their acidity, reaction selectivity, and stability during the run time [31,32]. Until now, the incorporation of different elements such as P, Co, Fe, Ni, Zn, etc. into zeolitic structures for improving their catalytic performance indifferent processes has been demonstrated [24,31–34]. For instance, Wei et al. have investigated the consequences of ZSM-5 modification by various metals on the catalytic cracking of naphtha. They found that ZSM-5 modified with Cu, Fe, and La could favor the production of BTX while those modified with P and Mg produced more light olefins (nearly 25% increase compared to the unmodified catalyst) [35]. Yoshimura et al. found that by the incorporation of La and P into the ZSM-5 catalyst in naphtha catalytic cracking, the yield of light olefins increased up to 10% [36,37]. Other researchers have investigated the promoting effects of Zn and Ni in the upgrading of light gas oil to gasoline [38]. They reported that these two promoters could reduce the olefin content of the produced gasoline while increasing the amounts of aromatics. Mohiuddin et al. [39] also assessed the effects of Fe and Cr promotion on the catalytic cracking of naphtha. They found that iron could enhance the ZSM-5 selectivity towards olefins to nearly twofold of unmodified zeolite while the introduction of Cr resulted in higher selectivity towards BTX products [39]. Miyatani et al. also reported on promotion effects of Ni and Pd over Y-type zeolite in hydrocracking of heavy petroleum oils. From their observations, the incorporation of these two promoters has led to the enhancement of the yield of gasoline cut to more than 70% [40]. A patent by Zhang et al. presented that doping of Mg, Ni, Zn, and Cu on phosphorus exchanged ZSM-5 catalyst could enhance light olefins yield [41]. An old patent by Pop et al. showed improved activity and selectivity of mordenite towards light olefins by incorporating of Cu, Ag, and Co [42,43]. In this paper, USY catalysts promoted with ferric chloride of varying iron loadings in the range of 0–5 wt% were applied to the catalytic cracking of heavy fuel oil at relatively mild operating conditions to evaluate the catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts in a set of microactivity test (MAT) experiments. The idea was that the process would be influenced by the presence of iron (from an iron chloride precursor) as the catalyst promoter. As such, the primary novel aspects of the work include the parent USY catalyst, the fuel oil feedstock, and the iron precursor that makes the dual modification scenario conceivable. The synthesized catalysts were characterized in detail with the aid of various analytical tools including XRD, FTIR, UV–vis DRS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, N2 physisorption, EDX, FESEM, and so forth. The employed heavy feedstock was also characterized by quantitative 1H and 13C NMR analyses. The apparent kinetics of the catalytic cracking reactions over the synthesized catalysts were also addressed using the Arrhenius model. The effect of residence time on the catalytic performance was also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The fuel oil fraction fed into the tubular reactor as the heavy feedstock was obtained from Tehran Refinery, with the specifications listed in Table 1 . FeCl3·6H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 97%) was purchased and used as the source of iron and chlorine in the present study. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis The parent USY catalyst was prepared as explained elsewhere [44,45]. The precursor aluminosilicate gel with a molar ratio of 0.42Na2O:0.074Al2O3:SiO2:17.13H2O was transferred to a stainless steel hydrothermal reactor to process at 102 °C for 24 h. The sample was dried overnight in an oven at 100 °C and calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h. The final ultra-stable zeolite (USY) was obtained through three-fold ion exchange with 1.0 M (NH4)2SO4 solution and a stabilization treatment in a steam flow of ˜25 mL/h at 600 °C for 2 h. FeCl3-doped USY catalysts with different iron contents (1, 3, and 5 wt%) were synthesized through dry impregnation. For this purpose, the parent USY catalyst was degassed, and the zeolite was impregnated to incipient wetness using an aqueous solution of FeCl3•6H2O to obtain the required loading. Finally, the catalysts were dried at 120 °C for 12 h followed by calcination in air with a flow rate of 70 mL/min at 650 °C for 4 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Room temperature powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were provided using Siemens, D5000 with Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ range of 4–88°. The adjusted step size and time per each step were 0.02 °C and 1 s, respectively. To get insight into the structural composition and chemistry of the samples, midrange Fourier-transform infrared (mid-FTIR) spectroscopy was performed on an Equinox 55 Bruker instrument. Prior to the FTIR analysis, samples were thoroughly dried and mixed with KBr powder. The adsorption/desorption isotherms and BET surface area were provided for all of the samples by measuring the N2 physisorption at –196 °C (77 K) on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 apparatus. To evaluate the amount and strength of the acidic sites over the catalyst surface, ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted on a NanoSord NF91 apparatus. For this purpose, nearly 0.05 g of catalyst was pretreated in He with a flow rate of 10 mL/min at 650 °C for 2 h to remove all physically bonded species, followed by an exposure to diluted stream of 5% NH3 as the probe molecule in He at 110 °C for 0.5 h. At the subsequent desorption step, the temperature of the catalyst surface was increased to 900 °C with a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min at a 10 mL/min flow rate in He. The desorbed molecules were detected by a calibrated thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The same procedure was followed in the pretreatment step for hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis. In the following step, the temperature was decreased to 40 °C in the helium atmosphere and kept for 2 h. Afterwards, a diluted flow of 5% hydrogen in argon (10 mL/min) passed over the catalyst surface. Meanwhile, the temperature was increased up to 850 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–vis DRS) was also performed on a PerkinElmer Lambda 365 instrument. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analyses were conducted over TESCAN apparatus using Au coated samples. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) measurements were performed with a SPECTRO XEPOS spectrometer. For further elemental analysis, inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, instrument Varian 720-ES) was employed. Prior to the analysis, the catalyst samples were hydrothermally dissolved in a mixture of HF, HNO3 and HCl for 90 min in a microwave oven. 2.4 Feed and product characterization The detailed characterization of heavy feedstock including density, pour point, flash point, ash content, and Conradson carbon residue (CCR) were determined based on ASTM standard methods of D1481, D5853, D92, D482, and D189, respectively. Feedstock viscosity was measured by falling ball method on AMVn Automated Micro Viscometer, Anton Paar. The sulfur content was established using gas chromatography (GC) on Agilent 6890 N equipped with a GC-GasPro column and a flame photometric detector (FPD). Structural features of the feedstock have been analyzed by quantitative 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy on a Bruker DRX 500 ANANCE spectrometer at room temperature. NMR sample was prepared by mixing a small amount of heavy hydrocarbon with CDCl3 as the NMR solvent. For obtaining quantitative proton spectra, an acquisition time of 1.59 s, a sweep width of 10,330.58 Hz, a flip angle of 90° (a 5 μs pulse) and a recycle delay of 6 s, and for all carbon spectra, an acquisition time of 1.04 s, a sweep width of 31,446.54 Hz, a flip angle of 90°, and a recycle delay of 4 s were set on the apparatus. Other relevant settings were presented in details elsewhere [21]. Liquid and gaseous products of the catalytic cracking process were analyzed on a gas chromatography (GC) instrument equipped with flame ionization and thermal conductivity detectors. 2.5 Catalytic cracking experiments Heavy fuel oil was applied as the hydrocarbon feedstock for atmospheric catalytic pyrolysis testing, which was performed in a tubular fixed-bed reactor (10 mm internal diameter) placed in an electrical furnace (Fig. 1 ). The temperature of the furnace was precisely controlled by a K-type controller. A specific amount of catalyst particles within the size range of 1.00–1.13 mm was placed in the middle of the reactor. Prior to the cracking reactions, the catalyst was activated in air with a flow rate of 70 mL/min at 650 °C for about 4 h. Then, the temperature was decreased to the reaction temperature in nitrogen with the same flow rate to provide an inert atmosphere prior to cracking reactions and also to sweep out the products obtained during the upgrading process. After that, the hydrocarbon feedstock was injected with the help of a diffusion pump with the required flow rate. The reactions were investigated at three temperature levels and three residence times. All products were collected in accordance with the microactivity test protocol. The liquid products were trapped in an ice bath, and the gaseous products were collected in a sample bag to be further analyzed on an off-line GC apparatus. The carbon balance was checked after each experiment, and it was better than 96% in all cases. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X-ray powder diffraction Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns recorded for the crystal structures of the synthesized catalysts. As is evident, intense diffractions were observed at 2θ = 6.3°, 15.8°, and 23.7° which were attributed to zeolite Y for the as-synthesized USY and 1Fe/USY catalysts. The absence of remarkable diffractions corresponding to metal oxide phases could indicate that Fe ions were either highly dispersed in the zeolite framework or appeared an amorphous phase outside of the USY lattice [39,46,47]. Nevertheless, the relative crystallinity of all catalysts was calculated using Eq. (1) in which I crys, I tot, and I const.bgr are respectively defined as the intensity of the crystalline peaks, total intensity (crystalline and amorphous peaks), and constant background intensity. (1) C r y s t a l l i n i t y % = ∑ I C r y s ∑ I t o t - ∑ I c o n s t . b g r The calculated relative crystallinity values for USY, 1Fe/USY, 3Fe/USY, and 5Fe/USY were 50%, 47%, 41%, and 27%, respectively. As evident, the degree of crystallinity of USY was slightly decreased after 1% iron doping. Upon increasing the amount of iron doped into the USY catalyst, the relative crystallinity decreased more significantly such that, in the case of 5Fe/USY, the relative crystallinity became approximately half that of the USY catalyst. Similar findings have been reported for iron-doped ZSM-5 catalysts [39]. The 2θ positions were slightly increased to higher values after doping to 1Fe/USY, due most possibly to the effect of partial dealumination [48] by the evolved hydrochloric acidic and pore contractions after the second calcination [46]. However, the peak positions shifted to lower 2θ values in the case of 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY (see the enlarged views of the diffractograms in Fig. S1). These changes (up to 0.12° shifts were observed) could be assigned to the incorporation of more Fe ions. The incorporation of 1 wt% iron into the zeolite framework changed the crystalline structure of the catalyst only slightly as was approved by almost the same sizes of unit cell parameters (24.385 Å) and cell volumes compared to the parent USY catalyst. However, in the case of 3 and 5 wt% iron-doping, the unit cell parameters (24.490 and 24.630 Å, respectively) and cell volumes changed more profoundly. The detectable changes are clear pieces of evidence for a net framework expansion that can be taken as an indication [49,50] for the incorporation of iron species into the zeolite framework. At the same time, we note that some iron species could replace extra-framework Al, which could not be genuinely detected by XRD [48]. The incorporation of iron into the USY lattice shifts the diffraction peaks to lower angles as the Fe–O bond is longer than that of Al–O (1.84–1.97 Å vs. 1.75 Å) [49,51]. More shifts could be expected with more Fe replacements along with the decrease in the crystal size, which were relevant to our doped catalysts. Analogous variations in the lattice parameters and the XRD patterns have been reported for isomorphous substitutions of transition metals for Al3+ in ZSM-22 and zeolite beta [49,52]. These changes confirm the incorporation of Fe3+ into the USY zeolite framework in the Fe-containing samples. Despite these alterations in the 2θ positions, all patterns were close enough to enable the conclusion that the impregnation of Fe into the USY framework did not change the basic FAU crystal structure of the parent USY [53]. This observation indicated the successful dispersion of the promoter on the surface of the catalyst [54]. However, the intensities of the observed peaks varied with the Fe loading. More precisely, except the first peak observed at 2θ = 6.3° which was strengthened by introducing up to 3 wt% of iron into the USY catalyst, all intensities decreased with an increased iron content, indicating that iron could be introduced into the zeolite structure and led to some displacements, e.g., as new nanosized amorphous phases within the zeolite cavities and/or on the surface of the catalyst [55]. The crystallite sizes of the catalysts were also calculated using the modified Scherrer equation [56]. Among the four samples, the parent USY possessed the largest crystallite size (27.3 nm), which was decreased upon iron doping due most probably to the progressive dealumination from the zeolite framework. As such, the crystallite size of 1Fe/USY was modest (24.6 nm) and the smallest sizes belonged to 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY with approximately the same size of 22 nm. 3.2 FTIR spectroscopy The FTIR spectra of the synthesized catalysts have been illustrated in Fig. 3 . The predominant features were observed at around 3444, 1635, 1204, 1072, 832, 520, and 457 cm–1, which could be assigned respectively to the surface hydroxyl group stretching, bending vibration of lattice water molecule, Si–O stretching, symmetrical bending of Si(Al)O4 tetrahedra, vibration of Si–O–Al, vibration of double five-membered ring in high-silica regions, and bending mode of TOT [29,57–59]. The slight shift of the asymmetric stretching vibration frequencies of the SiOT linkages to higher wavenumbers (e.g., from 1200 cm–1 for USY to 1204 cm–1 for 5Fe/USY) could imply [50,60,61] the partial dealumination of the catalyst upon the accompanying acid treatment during activation, with the change being almost independent of the loading (please refer to Fig. S2 for the enlarged view of up to 5.4 cm–1 changes in the vibrational frequencies). The sharp band at around 607 cm–1 (with a slight shift), which was intensified upon iron doping was attributed to FeO stretching [62]. Moreover, a slight increase was observed in the ratio of the transmittance peaks of the Al-containing bands that are prone to iron replacement and the band at 607 cm–1 which is connected with the FeO stretching to the principal band assigned to SiO (1204 cm–1) upon Fe modification. This observation signified that FeO (with higher polarity than AlO) replaced the extra-framework Al species bonded to OSi (as confirmed by the XRD pattern) or the hydroxyl groups on the surface of the zeolite, which could, in turn, alter the acidity of the synthesized catalysts. The increased intensity of the TO band with the reduced Al content could be explained by the fact that the SiO distance is shorter than the AlO bond and Si has a higher electronegativity than Al. 3.3 Low-temperature nitrogen adsorption Table 2 underlines the textural properties of the synthesized catalysts using the post-treatment of N2 physisorption data. As is evident, the incorporation of iron as a promoter in the zeolite structure with up to 1 wt% loading enhanced its surface area to 657.3 m2/g, which is more than the reported value for the parent USY catalyst (637.6 m2/g). In contrast, further increasing of the promoter loading led to decrease in the catalyst surface area, such that by applying 3 wt% or more of iron, the surface area reduced to even less than that of the parent USY catalyst. The same trend held true for the total pore volume of the catalysts, indicating that the surface area changed principally as a consequence of pore blockage. More strictly, the total pore volume of USY catalyst (0.31 cm3/g) was quite lower than that of 1Fe/USY (0.34 cm3/g). In the same line, by further increasing the iron content (up to 5 wt%), the total pore volume of the synthesized catalyst decreased significantly. These changes stemmed from both the accumulation of the iron oxide nanoclusters and acid treatment of the framework during the activation. The latter was most likely to enlarge the micropore size of the cavities compared to the original USY catalyst. This enlargement was more severe in the case of iron loading to prepare 1Fe/USY (with a micropore size of 1.26 nm) from the parent USY (with a micropore size of 1.16 nm). In addition, the mesopore size of the modified catalysts was changed (decreased) more considerably with respect to the parent USY when compared to the micropores (see Table 2). One may conclude that the mesopore structure was tightened with iron loading, due most possibly to the partial collapse of wider cavities and the deposition of metal species on their walls. Overall, the incorporation of iron up to 1 wt% led to reasonable improvements in the textural properties of the USY catalyst. Fig. S3 displays the N2 physisorption isotherms of the synthesized catalysts. All catalyst samples exhibited sharp nitrogen uptakes at relative pressures much smaller than 0.47 (mainly P/P 0< 0.02), pointing to the prevalent microporosity of their structure. However, the presence of hysteresis loops in these isotherms at higher pressures signified the capillary condensation effect arising from the presence of a considerable portion of mesopores in the catalyst structure. Based on the IUPAC classifications [29,31,63,64], the isotherms were all of type IV. However, in case of USY and 1Fe/USY, type H4 hysteresis loops associated with the adsorption in mesopores of the catalysts was observed, while for 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY a pseudotype H2 hysteresis was detected indicating an interconnected pore system, which leads to constrictions in their mesostructures [29,65]. 3.4 Elemental analysis To get more insights into the chemical composition of the samples, the results of the elemental mappings and the EDX analyses are shown in Fig. S4 and Table 3 , respectively. As is obvious, the best homogeneity and distribution of iron species on the surface of the synthesized catalysts belonged to 1Fe/USY. Although the surface iron species were apparently more abundant on 3Fe/USY, more aggregates could also be spotted on its surface. The formation of these aggregates became more severe in the case of 5Fe/USY as is clearly shown in the associated elemental maps. Table 3 highlights that the Si/Al ratio of the prepared catalysts decreased by increasing the iron loading. This observation further confirms our previous conclusion on the partial in situ dealumination from the interior cavities to the external surface of the catalysts assuming that the EDX penetration depth of electrons has been smaller than agglomerated particulates of the modified catalysts, thus giving information about the surface of the crystals only. Evidence for analogous aluminum enrichment on the surface has been reported previously [66] for the ZSM-5 crystals. Overall, the values of iron loading from EDX and ICP were in fair agreement. 3.5 Acidity measurements Ammonia TPD can be applied to determine the strength and density of the acidic sites of metal-loaded USY catalysts. The obtained signals are shown in Fig. S5. Two main regions were identified in the TPD graphs on the basis of the two peaks that occurred at lower (LT) and higher (HT) temperatures. The HT region corresponds to stronger acid sites, and the related peak position signifies the strength of the acidic sites. From the area of the TPD profiles, we note that the acid amount was decreased by increasing the iron loading (from 0.69 mmol NH3 per gram of USY to 0.56 mmol NH3 per gram of 5Fe/USY). In terms of the distribution of acid sites, however, the 1Fe/USY catalyst showed the highest strong-to-weak (HT/LT) acid ratio (2.65) compared to the corresponding values for the parent USY (2.24) and 5Fe/USY (2.43). At the same time, 1Fe/USY presented the highest acidity of 0.71 mmol/g. We further note that the LT peak could also be assigned to the interaction between the molecular sieve and ammonia molecules via hydrogen bonds [67]. As the unmodified USY catalyst has been active in the catalytic cracking reactions and the main acidity feature of the catalyst has appeared at the LT region, however, its connection with the cracking performance of active sites of the catalyst could not be ignored. The parent USY demonstrated the primary signal for ammonia desorption at ca. 207 °C. The area of this peak was decreased by increasing the iron loading. The lower density of acid sites in Fe-loaded samples could be attributed to the higher degree of Al extraction in the modified samples [68]. For 1Fe/USY, a new signal was observed at approximately 329 °C. This signal might be connected with new stronger Brønsted acid sites [39] or strong Lewis acid sites [68] appeared after dealumination and metal loading. FTIR analysis of adsorbed pyridine makes a clear distinction between the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites using the integrated Lambert–Beer law and the extinction coefficients ε B = 0.73 ± 0.04 cm/μmol and ε L = 0.64 ± 0.04 cm/μmol, respectively, such that the IR bands around 1540 and 1450 cm–1 can be acceptably assigned to the pyridine adsorbed on Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively [69–73]; more details are found in the supporting information. The integrated areas for the two acid types enabled the determination of L/(L + B) ratio. The estimated values from these calculations indicated that L/(L + B) was increased from 0.56 for the USY to 0.73 for 1Fe/USY. Therefore, more Lewis acid sites have appeared after the modification. This alteration could further bring about a synergy at new Brønsted–Lewis acid pairs that play essential roles in the activation of alkanes [74,75]. The strong Lewis acidity can originate, e.g., from stabilized FeCl3 species on the surface. Although the second peak was also detected for 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY, its intensity was reduced by increasing the iron doping. This alteration shows that these strong acidic sites are changed or masked by further loading of iron; it also implied that 1Fe/USY could operate differently when applied to the upgrading process. 3.6 Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra Fig. 4 shows the UV–vis reflectance spectra of the fabricated catalysts in the wavelength range of 200–1100 nm. Evidently, two distinct patterns were detected for the synthesized catalysts, one for the 1Fe/USY, and the other for the 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY samples. A substantial overlap of the bands indicated the presence of different (isolated, polymeric, and crystalline iron oxide) species on the catalysts [76]. The spectrum of 1Fe/USY exhibited three adsorption bands centered at 202, 307, and 400 nm and two shoulders at about 234 and 796 nm. The intensity of the first band was reduced upon further loading of iron. Whereas the intensity of the second band at ˜307 nm was maximized for 3Fe/USY and changed to a shoulder on 5Fe/USY, the most intense absorption band on 5Fe/USY was visible at ca. 373 nm. In addition, the first shoulder of 1Fe/USY was upshifted to about 267 nm on 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY. While the intensity of the low-energy shoulder due to the d–d charge transfer transitions [24,77] was reduced from 1Fe/USY to 3Fe/USY, it was further intensified (816 nm) for the 5Fe/USY catalyst. Overall, the spectra clearly confirmed the presence of magnetite (γ-Fe3O4) species in 3Fe/USY, which were mixed with hematite species in 5Fe/USY [78]. They also showed the slight move to the β-FeOOH phase in 3Fe/USY which was slightly changed to a γ phase in 5Fe/USY [78] as also confirmed by the reddish-yellow color of the samples [79]. As the positions of the bands at the high energy region did not match those of a ligand-to-metal (Cl→Fe) charge-transfer (LMCT) transitions observed for [FeCl4]– anions reported previously [80] and that the elemental analysis revealed negligible concentrations of chlorine on the samples, the observed signals in the high-energy range of the spectra were attributed to (p–d)O→Fe LMCT transitions due to the oxygen ligands surrounding the dopant ions, typically assigned to isolated Fe3+ cations in framework positions [68,76,77,80,81]. Overall, according to the related classifications [68,76], the UV–vis spectra confirmed the prevalence of isolated Fe3+ on 1Fe/USY and the abundance of small oligonuclear Fe3+ oxo-clusters on 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY. Moreover, the bands appearing at 234–307 nm clearly pointed to the abundance of highly dispersed isomorphously substituted tetrahedral Fe3+ species in 1Fe/USY and octahedral Fe3+ complexes in 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY [24,52,68,77,80,81]. Tentatively, the dispersed iron species on 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY were found mostly in the extra-framework positions [77,81]. Two broad shoulders at 470 and 500 nm were also detected in the visible region of the spectra of 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY respectively, which can be assigned to larger Fe3O4 nanoclusters and agglomerated Fe3+cations (e.g. iron hydroxide clusters) located mainly on the external surface of the zeolite [68,76,77,80,81]. 3.7 H2 temperature-programmed reduction The H2-TPR profiles of the modified catalysts have been presented in Fig. 5 to probe the reducibility of the iron species. As is shown for 1Fe/USY, a single reduction peak was found at 544 °C, which could be assigned to the reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO. In the case of 5Fe/USY, however, a multiple reduction pattern was detected. The first peak centered at 405 °C was attributed to the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+ and the one at around 600 °C could be ascribed to the reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO. The H2-TPR profiles revealed that the iron species on the modified catalysts with higher Fe loadings were less reducible, as evinced by their peak positions shifted to higher temperatures. In such a manner that the observed peak at around 543.6 °C for 1Fe/USY shifted to the temperature of 600 °C for 5Fe/USY. 3.8 FESEM imaging The morphologies of the samples were investigated by the FESEM images, as shown in Fig. 6 . Small well-shaped aggregates were observed on the surface of the iron-doped catalysts, which could be attributed to the impregnated iron species and the structural changes due to the Al extraction from the parent USY sample. Upon increasing the iron loading to 5 wt%, the size and number of these aggregates increased, and larger nanoclusters of iron were found at the external surface of the catalysts, making the iron distribution less homogeneous. The resulting pore blockage by the nanoclusters formed on the outer surface of 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY, which was also confirmed by the obvious reduction in their total pore volumes (indicated from the N2 physisorption analysis) is expected to result in poor performances in the fuel oil conversion. Average particulate sizes of 320, 290, 186, and 119 nm were estimated from the FESEM images for USY, 1Fe/USY, 3Fe/USY, and 5Fe/USY, respectively. The decreasing order was in fair correspondence with the trend of crystal sizes from the XRD patterns (vide supra). 3.9 Catalytic performance The main performance data for the improved upgrading of refinery fuel oil with the modified catalysts have been presented in Fig. 7 . Detailed product distribution can be found in Table S1. As can be seen in Fig. 7 (upper panel), the 1Fe/USY and 3Fe/USY catalysts tended to produce more gases than liquids (respectively with 78.64 and 63.42 wt% gas yields) while the other two catalysts with approximately the same amounts of gas yields (˜42 wt%) favored liquid fuel production. About 34.62 wt% of the obtained products over the parent USY catalyst was contributed by gasoline, indicating that it was the most suitable catalyst for obtaining light (C5–C11) liquid fuel components. The corresponding values on 5Fe/USY, 3Fe/USY, and 1Fe/USY were 29.29, 21.65, and 16.02 wt%, respectively (see Table S1). Quite more than half of the produced gases with all of the samples were light olefins, implying the successful preparation of catalysts for these petrochemicals of value. As is evident, the total light olefins obtained over 1Fe/USY (56.59 wt%) with the predominance of propylene (22.82 wt%) was significantly higher than those on other catalysts, indicating that a 1 wt% loading of iron species from a FeCl3 precursor improved remarkably the catalyst selectivity towards light olefins (the lower panel in Fig. 7). Although the olefin productivity of 3Fe/USY (45.61 wt%) was lower than 1Fe/USY, it was still superior to the parent USY catalyst (30.39 wt%). In the case of 5Fe/USY, however, no considerable changes in the olefin production were observed (30.69 wt%) with respect to the parent USY sample. Although the severity factors of propylene-to-ethylene ratio [7] or the methane-to-olefins index [5] are slightly lower in the case of modified USY catalysts considering the dehydrogenation-to-cracking activity, this subtle weakness is totally compensated for by the considerably higher performance of the modified catalysts in terms of light olefins production. Fig. 8 depicts the yields of major products in terms of the reaction temperature (upper panel) as well as the space velocity (lower panel). As can be seen, at higher temperatures (˜550 °C), 1Fe/USY was more likely to produce gases (78.64 wt%) than liquids, while at a lower temperature (˜450 °C), more liquid fuels (33.58 wt%) was obtained over this modified catalyst. The amount of light olefins achieved at 450 °C with 1Fe/USY was less than half of the olefins produced at 550 °C (23.3 wt% vs. 56.6 wt%). Nonetheless, propylene with a 10.7 wt% yield still occupied the major proportion of the obtained light olefins at the lower temperature, confirming the propylene-oriented nature of the iron-loaded USY catalyst. When the impact of higher space velocities is concerned, Fig. 8 (lower panel) informs interestingly that a threefold increase in the space velocity to a high WHSV (54.9 h–1) resulted merely in a slight decrease in the catalytic productivity of 1Fe/USY, which proved the excellent performance of the synthesized catalyst. More strictly, 1Fe/USY produced 47.1 wt% of light olefins (composed of 13.2 wt% ethylene, 18.7 wt% propylene, and about 15.2 wt% butenes) from the heavy feedstock at short contact times, which was still higher than the olefins produced with 3Fe/USY at much longer contact times (WHSV of 18.3 h–1). Fig. 9 illustrates the variation of the reaction rate with temperature within a range of 450–550 °C at constant WHSV of 18.3 h–1. Evidently, the experimental data followed the Arrhenius model satisfactorily with a correlation coefficient close to 1. The obtained apparent activation energy and the pre-exponential factor toward light olefins from the catalytic conversion of the heavy feedstock over the optimum (1Fe/USY) catalyst were estimated to be 43.99 kJ/mol and 1.81 s–1, respectively. 4 Conclusion Ultra-stable Y zeolite (USY) was modified through dry impregnation of different amounts of iron(III) chloride on the surface of the catalyst with the aim to provide an improved activity as well as a better selectivity toward light olefins (along with the lighter liquid fuels) in the catalytic cracking of refinery fuel oil. According to the initial hypothesis, a suitable selection of iron precursor for Fe doping could also lead to a proper dealumination from the zeolite matrix in the course of activation, which was able to adjust the acidity of the catalyst and prohibit the formation of hydrogen-depleted depositions on the catalyst active sites which ultimately lead to immediate catalyst deactivation. The catalysts were synthesized through dry impregnation with various iron contents. The synthesized catalysts were fully characterized using different analytical techniques including XRD, FTIR, UV–vis DRS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, EDX, N2 physisorption, ICP-EOS, XRF, and FESEM. The FTIR, XRD, and EDX results revealed a simultaneous dealumination and iron doping with FeCl3 modifier. Although the parent USY was of a hierarchical structure and possessed entirely satisfactory properties, a favorable structural modification was accomplished with 1 wt% doing of iron as found from isotherm analyses. The presence of highly dispersed iron species on 1Fe/USY was confirmed by UV–vis spectra, which was progressively changed to larger nanoclusters and aggregates on 3Fe/USY and 5Fe/USY. Thanks to the unique interplay of dealumination and doping in 1Fe/USY, the optimum doping was expected to be around 1 wt% of iron. The obtained MAT results revealed that a maximum production of light olefins (more than 56 wt% from the virgin feedstock, comprising propylene as its principal constituent) could be achieved over the 1Fe/USY catalyst at atmospheric pressure and 550 °C. Altering the reaction temperature to 450 °C caused the yield of light olefins to decrease to less than a half (nearly 23 wt%). Instead, more liquid fuels (33.6 wt% vs. 21.2 wt% at 550 °C) were produced, with the abundance of gasoline components. An increase in the space velocity by more than three times over 1Fe/USY caused the amounts of light olefins to slightly decrease to 47.1 wt%, which was still higher than the obtained values over the parent USY catalyst (30.4 wt%) at a WHSV of 18.1 h–1. The results clearly proved that a modification of the USY catalyst with FeCl3 dopant bestows an enhanced activity to this catalyst for the production of light olefins, particularly propylene. coredata.dc:description: Herein, ultra-stable Y zeolite (USY) catalysts modified with iron doping (1, 3, and 5 wt%) using FeCl3•6H2O as a precursor have been investigated. Detailed characterization of the synthesized catalysts was implemented through different analytical techniques including XRD, FTIR, UV–vis DRS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, N2 physisorption, EDX, FESEM, ICP-EOS, and XRF. The strong Lewis acidity of the precursor bestowed improved acidic properties to the parent USY besides a satisfactory partial dealumination of the zeolite structure. The optimal dispersion and structural properties were obtained in the case of 1 wt% doping of iron, which eventually led to superb olefin productivity (more than 56 wt%) in the upgrading of refinery fuel oil at mild operating conditions (atmospheric pressure and 550 °C). The optimum catalyst (1Fe/USY) has undergone further experiments with varying temperatures and space velocities to assess the apparent kinetics based on the Arrhenius model. A threefold increase in the space velocity (from 18.3 to 54.9 h–1) only slightly reduced the olefin productivity of the catalyst (to 47.1 wt%), which was still notable from a heavy feedstock. Reduction of the reaction temperature to 450 °C led to a decrease in the olefins yield to less than a half (23.3 wt%). Overall, the modified catalysts were capable of producing a high amount of light olefins from heavy fuel oil, with an orientation toward propylene as the most favored building block in the petrochemical industries.
coredata.dc:title: Dual role of ferric chloride in modification of USY catalyst for enhanced olefin production from refinery fuel oil
